segments.text: The following podcast contains explicit language.
Hello and welcome to the Slate Political Gavfest for March 21st, 2019.
The president is not a white supremacist edition.
I am David Plots of Atlas Obscura.
I'm in Washington, DC joining me.
Telephonically or not telephonically, but electronically is Emily
Bazzlon of the New York Times Magazine and Yale Law School from the Yale studios.
Hello, Emily and New Haven.
Hello, David.
Welcome back from the West Coast.
Thank you.
It's good to be back on the correct coast again.
And John Dickerson appears to be on vacation.
That's going to be what I'm going to guess.
He's, he's not here.
And as a result, we have the great pleasure of welcoming you back.
Gavfest favorite, Jamel Bowie, New York Times columnist, Jamel.
It's great to have you back.
Is this your first time back as a New York Times person as opposed to as a slate person?
I think so.
But yeah, this is the first time back.
And thank you for having me.
It's going to all be different now.
Who knows how exactly, but it will all be transformed.
There's a lot of New York Times in this year.
You guys are probably fellow union members and you probably like eat lunch in the cafeteria together
and stuff.
Actually, definitely not because neither of you ever is in New York.
Yeah, we don't need in the cafeteria.
I'm in the union.
I don't know about Jamel though.
Do you know, do you know, do you know, do you know, do you know, is that part of being a columnist?
No, I'm part of being a columnist is that I'm outside of the bargaining unit.
Although of course, solidarity forever.
That's a topic for another day.
Right.
On this week's show, the Christchurch massacre and white supremacy.
What is this new?
I mean, is it a new fascination?
This new rise of white supremacy.
Where does it come from?
How can we crush it?
Then Beto Biden, Bernie, finally, finally for once.
Can there be a straight white man as a Democratic Democratic nominee for president?
At last, maybe it's possible.
Then the Electoral College.
Can it be abolished?
Should it be abolished?
How would it be abolished?
Plus we will have cocktail chatter and do not forget that next week, Wednesday, March 27th, we are going to be live at the Lincoln Theater here and
Washington, DC.
You can get tickets for that live show at slate.com slash live.
And it's going to be wonderful.
We're going to have new Democratic Congresswoman Lauren Underwood joining us as a guest.
And we are, of course, going to preview, give you a sneak preview into Emily's great new book charged.
So we're going to talk about that.
And we're, of course, we'll go over the political news of the week.
So go to slate.com slash live to get tickets.
And Jamelle, we're going to be in Charlottesville on April 12th, Friday, April 12th.
That's right.
Tom, Tom Festival.
Yeah, I am joining you.
Twice in a month.
That's very good news for us.
Go to slate.com slash live.

So the Christchurch massacre, 50 people murdered by a gunman at two mosques, a white supremacist, Australian is horrified people around the world, but it has not horrified enough people apparently, and it's not horrified universally.
Jamelle, I think what's been so disturbing is that this shooter, like so many
recent murders and would-be murders and terrorists in the last couple of years, was motivated or is motivated by a white supremacist ideology.
And it was cheered on by internet supporters.
What is going on with the rise of this white supremacist movement?
And is it a rise?
Has it just always been there?
We just never noticed it.
White power ideology and white power movements have been kind of a background development in American and the transitional Western world for some time.
If it's manifestos to be believed, if it's documented to be believed, he is a white supremacist.
He believes that white people or people, you know, defined as white or headed for extinction because of immigration in their marriage.

But he also holds other beliefs that don't so neatly fit, given that the best way to describe him is as holding a white power ideology, which is sort of inclusive of white supremacy, but also is a bit broader.
It includes xenophobia.
It includes anti-Islam.
It includes anti-Semitism, especially.

And I think it would be right to see this shooter not just as part of this kind of internet radicalization, but also we should connect him to a shooter that maybe was at the vanguard of that, Dylan Roof and Charles Tlector-Lina.
I think we should connect them to the shooter Anders Brevick in Norway.
Norway, right.
Norway, who also sounded a similar white power note to people going all the way back to the 1980s, to David Lane, to propagandists like William Pierce.
The important thing is just to note that this is part of a lineage of actors, of movements that have taken different forms at different times, but kind of, there are broad and clear continuities.
What is new about this?
I mean, when I look at this, what has happened in the last few years is that the ability of the internet to mobilize and connect people and also to broadcast to each other is one big difference.
There's this tremendous anxiety fanned by these white nationalists, but also fanned by real events about immigration, particularly in Europe.
This has been a total panic.
There's some sense that there's economic insecurity all around as globalism grows, and then there's Trump.

And then there's the way in which Trump has given cover and given moral cover to people who espoused despicable, horrible things, the normal condemnation that the United States at the highest level, and that all the arm of government usually bestows upon anybody like this has vanished.
And therefore, people, I think, feel there's a loss of moral credibility and a loss of ability to condemn this that didn't used to exist.
Is that what is new?
And which of those forces is most important of the new forces?
Well, I think that's a good summary.

I mean, another thing to bring in here, and this connects to what Jamel was saying about this kind of strain of toxic ideology that connects some of these shooters, the United States, the FBI had much more attention to the United States.

And there's much more attention specifically focused on white nationalist violence, which it basically stopped working on because of the politics, because any kind of focus on these white people in their danger was seen as a threat to American values in a way that focusing on terrorism
and being able to get into radical Islamic ideology was not.
So, you know, I think there's just been a loss of law enforcement focus, which doesn't, obviously, directly relate to New Zealand, but is something that should matter a lot here.
And as we see this replication, understanding that this really is a set of beliefs that consistently, or at least periodically, leads people to violence seems crucial for preventing it.
In terms of the factors you just listed, I think it's important to talk about the social media part of this.
And I mean, in some sense, Trump is just like part of this, right?
Because he's such a presence on social media and is successful in that medium.

But I mean, there was just this obvious way that this killing was just like made to go viral, and then a lot of criticism of Facebook and YouTube for their sort of usual rather dismal efforts in preventing that.

But I thought there was a really pretty persuasive New York Times up end by Charlie Warzel, pointing out that, yeah, I mean, it's a problem that the social media companies don't have a way to really shut down the dissemination of this kind of video and images.

But more of the problem that they don't have a way of monitoring or encouraging their social media communities to build that prevents people like this from finding each other and really elevating and amplifying their messages.
And that is just like such a huge challenge that I think the platforms haven't even really faced yet.

But I mean, there was a BuzzFeed piece and there was a Wired piece both on the subject, which point out that they do have the capacity because they've deployed that capacity against ISIS and against the Islamist terror videos and horror and torture videos that made their way around.
And they made it much harder for people to connect with each other and to find things that would radicalize them.
But they have been...
Right, and I feel like that proves my point. They have the capacity they haven't used it yet.
They don't have the willingness to use it because this white power, white supremacist ideology is so connected to political movements that have huge power, especially in the United States.

Right, and we see Republican politicians, including Trump this week, attacking Facebook and other social media platforms for their supposed bias against conservatives, when in fact, I think you can make the argument that the companies are actually bending over backwards.
And that it's not to appear biased and that that has created this breeding ground for this really dangerous dissemination of information.
Jamel, what's your take on how important social media is in this?

I think social media is important in that it sort of broadens the scope of people who could be drawn in, who hold kind of beliefs that are maybe just like a few notches down the spectrum from these ideologies.
The internet makes it pretty easy and social media makes it pretty easy for someone who in the past may have never encountered, like someone articulating a coherent version of them.
People who may have never necessarily been exposed to these things can kind of get sucked in very quickly and decide to, depending on them as individuals in the context they live in,
decide to act as a result.

What did you guys think of the Prime Minister of New Zealand's call not to say the name of the shooter this week and to not allow the media and I guess all of us to be used to kind of further his fame?
I appreciate it because I didn't catch what his name was and so it allowed me not to remember to use it on the show.
No, I actually need someone to advise me on what the right response there is.

The last person who talks to me about it always convinces me, yes you should use the name and talk all about his ideology and then the next person who convinces me, no, don't use his name, don't talk about the ideology.
Jamel?
I feel like the ideology is separate from the fame of the individual, right?

It is important to identify the ideology and explore it because we need to be able to locate where this violence is coming from and have some sort of sense of where it's likely to come from, but I'm really drawn to this notion that we buy broadcasting people's names and photographs feed into this
like ego, maniacal desire they have for attention and that it creates this, could create this kind of copycat syndrome.
Right, I'm in the same place. I don't think it's necessary to talk about the name of the shooter details of his life show pictures.
I think all of that is irrelevant. We don't necessarily give that kind of attention to ordinary criminals.
I don't think we should give it to terrorists either, but it's critical.

I agree to talk about the ideology, to talk about the ideas, the social context for all of this in order to be able to stop it because otherwise what ends up happening is these things are treated as basically like acts of God, freak accidents, and we move on until the next one.
Clearly, that's just not the case as we continue doing that. It threatens people's lives.
I mean, most of the attacks in Western countries over the last what five years have been by white power extremists straight up.
They constitute kind of like the violent threat to ordinary people.
And if you want to go broader than that, you look at the things in the last 150 years or so of Western history, what is actually threatened Western democracies?
It has been viciously violent white supremacists, whether that's the civil war in the reaction to reconstruction in the United States, whether that's Nazi Germany in Europe.
So we got to treat this stuff as the potentially existential threat it could be.

One of the things that I think is so difficult about treating it as an existential threat and about stomping out and quashing it and making it as morally unacceptable as it should be is the ironic nature of it and the way in which certain adherence to it
use irony and use a distancing effect and use joking and use a kind of form of comic trolling as a way of hiding what they're doing.
There's a way of saying they can always hide behind this idea. We're just playing around. We're just being playful.
It's just memes. It's just the Pepe the Frog. Like there's a frog. It has this kind of cover of comedy.

You're just not in on the joke or you just can't take a joke. It reminds me weirdly, one of the things is the whole kind of, I mean this is less true of the actual murderers than of the people who fall short of that, reminds me of what Abbie Hoffman used to do on the left, which was this performative

undermining of the culture, which always had an element of jokiness, but was also simultaneously deadly serious. It's very effective. It's very hard to inoculate against that because if you take it completely seriously, people are like, why are you taking this totally seriously?
This is just, we're just playing around here. If you don't take it seriously, then people are actually galvanized and go out and murder people.
It's where PewDiePie, this YouTube phenomenon, who's a joker, but also clearly turns people in a dark way, or makes it easier for people to turn a dark way.
That kind of ironic piece of this is very unsettling to me. Do you guys have any thoughts on that or ways to deal with it?
Yeah, it seems to me that the memes on social media are so much like the political cartoons of old, and what's fun about them is their sort of extremity and their humor and sarcasm.

It is hard to see those things as dangerous. As soon as something is at all funny, even if it's really dark humor, part of at least my responses to think like, okay, you don't want to be the curmudgeon who is like,
thinking of it purely as political propaganda. And yet it is absolutely possible to just turn humor into this tool of really dangerous ideas.
I think it's important to note that this sort of trolling as politics isn't new, isn't novel. My kind of area of subject expertise is kind of like the 19th century post-ivore period.
You can understand, say, the first iteration of the Ku Klux Klan, as in part being a big troll, right? Like they dressed up in these ridiculous costumes. They give themselves these ridiculous names.
They pretend to be ghosts, the scare, the former slaves. It's an opportunity for sort of like, japes on people that they hate.
It is sincere, but it's expressed in this joking, trolling way. In doing that, it kind of gives space for people to behave in violent, anti-social ways.

If you, Jean-Paul Sartre, in a 1946 essay called the anti-Semite and Jew, says, the way he describes it, he says, they know that their remarks are frivolous, open to challenge, but they are amusing themselves.

It is their adversary who is obliged to use words responsibly since he believes in words. They like to play discourse for by giving ridiculous reasons. They discredit the seriousness of their interlocutors.
It's sort of a use of absurdity and trolling to get a rise out of opponents and also to attempt to set the terms of the discourse, which gives them a kind of power.
So I see this too as operating in a tradition. This is just kind of how these people roll.
Those historical examples were great, Jamil. Thanks for bringing that in.
I know, I got it. I think I got it at the tip of your tongue. It's really beautiful.
You didn't have that at the tip of your tongue. He was like, oh, they're going to mention irony. I got that.
I got some start. He just had his notes about the title of that start essay or have you had a little bit of a title?
You mentioned it, and then I know that essay exists, and I know that line exists, so I kind of just couldn't have a Google search.
Nice. Well played, friend. That was fast Googling.
Slate Plus members, you get bonus segments on the Gavfest and other Slate podcasts. Gavfest named one of the 100 most important podcasts by New York magazine,
so you definitely need a bonus segment there.
So today, that bonus segment Jamil and Emily are going to talk about traveling in the south,
because Emily has just done her first travels in the south, and Jamil is a southerner.
Wait, not the whole south, okay? Not like I'd never been south before.
Whatever. Why?
I went to Mississippi and Alabama.
Fine, and that's it.
In the deep south, the deepest part of the deep south.
You make me sound like a total Neanderthal.
Neanderthals always get such a bad rap. Anyway, go to Slate.com.
That's true, maybe that's unfair.
Anyway, we make fun of them, but we wipe them out. It's not cool.
All right, I take it back. Sorry, Neanderthals.
You were nice people, I'm sure. Better than humans.
Go to Slate.com, Gavfest Plus, to become a member today.
Biden, Beto, Bernie, the killer bees. Not sure why Booted Judge.
Booted Judge, however you say that guy's name, why he is not there too, I guess, because he's not straight, maybe.
But anyway, the three straight white males have been getting lots more attention in the Democratic primary,
and a lot of money, but a lot more attention than you might expect.
Might hope for. Might think would be their due.
Bernie Sanders brought in $5.9 million in his first day of fundraising.
It was almost immediately surpassed by Beto Arroic who brought in $6.1 million.
Joe Biden is in his inimitable Biden way, is signaling that he's about to announce that he's going to run for president,
and he's leading in almost all the early polls, although I don't know what that means.
We can discuss or not.
So, Emily, what is the purpose of a Joe Biden candidacy?
Why should it exist?
He is old. He represents a kind of accommodationism that seems impossible today.
But what, I mean, should it exist?
The argument is that the Democrats need some moderate pragmatic candidates who have the power to rally people broadly across the country,
especially white people, especially the white working class who get lots of attention,
and that Biden will be able to pick off Trump supporters that the other candidates won't be able to do.
I'm not really sure why we think Biden would be better at that than Beto.
Maybe Jamelle can parse that one for me, but Biden's supposed to be the sort of establishment part of the Democratic Party.
You know, he has his like glad-handing way, Delaware ways, and that's supposed to have this broader appeal,
especially to older voters and white voters that some of the other candidates are assumed to lack.
I don't know if that's really fair, but that seems like the conventional wisdom read on Biden.
I mean, Jamelle, you had this great phrase that you can defeat Trump without defeating Trumpism,
and you use Biden as the embodiment of that. What did you mean by that?
So, I wrote that apppropos of a Washington Post story about Biden's past,
like in his first decade in national politics as an opponent of bussing to integrate schools.
And if you look at it in the moment, in the 1970s, you can't be a proponent of integration and an opponent of bussing.
In practice, opposing bussing just meant opposing integration.
And Biden was a vociferous opponent using language that if we heard it now, we would sort of be taken aback at how frankly racist it is.
And if you use that as the starting point for Biden's career and kind of just look forward,
what you see is a political figure who opposed bussing was harshly tough on crime,
kind of embraced in full kind of the carceral politics of the late 80s and 90s was a fervent drug warrior who backed welfare reform
and kind of that whole set of policies. And what that looks like is a politician who's kind of a load star is the suburban white voter
who is afraid of kind of racial change or believes that black people or low-income black people in particular
either need to be like controlled or disciplined. That there's a pathological culture and it threatens kind of the prosperity of these places.
It's already taken down cities and it needs to be controlled.
Whether or not Biden personally believed that it's sort of irrelevant.
Those are the politics that I think he was supporting.
Looking at how he frames his appeal now to kind of an idealized, like white working class person to sort of what, you know, what like a early 20th century Marxist might call the labor aristocracy,
your firefighters, your police officers, your factory workers, your hard hats.

Looking at how he pitches his appeal to those people in particular, it's not really not crazy to wonder if, yeah, Biden can beat Trump, but would he end up beating Trump by basically being a more authentic version of what Trump is supposed to be.
And even if that does not come with the racial demagoguery, I don't think it would.
It would still be bolstering kind of the assumptions beneath what Trump is doing, that there is actually a hierarchy of workers and some of them deserve our attention and support more than others.
Emily, I'm sure you're relieved that there are three straight white guys who seem to be serious contenders for the Democratic nomination.
Are you just offering me up a big fat meatball?
No, why does it matter?
I'm really excited that they're the ones we're talking about today and that two of them are the ones who have raised so much more money than everyone else.
That makes my heart beat.
How can we talk about it? How do we grapple with this fact?
Because obviously it unsettles people in both directions.
So this is a kind of a better one, especially when people talk about better.
It's like, oh, he's young, he's handsome, he's so charismatic and appealing and he'll reach people.
And it's troublesome, but also maybe there's something to it? I don't know.
I don't know.
I mostly feel agnostic about all of these candidates.
And in one sense, I resent how eternally long this Democratic primary process is going to go for.
It's just going to be forever.
I mean, it's like a year, a whole year.
We're going to be talking about this.
On the other hand, I guess at the end, we're going to know there are strikes and weaknesses on nauseam.
And hopefully the party will make a good choice.
I don't know about the best choice, a good choice.
Like it will all be out on the table. I don't know.
So I don't want to be stridently opposing or for anyone right now because it just seems useless and also not my job.
But I do.
One does notice the way in which at least some people on the party are moving.
The other thing, though, to be fair is that Biden and Bernie and Beto just played all the similarities in the fact that it's fun to say their names together.
They do represent different kind of strains of the party.
I mean, Bernie Sanders is standing over to the left calling for big spending programs in government occupying that lane in a way that obviously he did in 2016.
Beto seems much sort of gauzier to me.
It was interesting to see him not embrace the Sanders version of Medicare for all this week.
I kind of like that policy debate because I do wonder if a lot of Americans would rather choose than be told that they have to move to a single payer system.
And then, of course, Biden has these different attributes we were just talking about.
So I don't know. I don't know what to say.

I mean, you can also argue that some of the other candidates like Kamala Harris or Elizabeth Warren who are women and people of color, a Cory Booker, a person of color, that their failure to fundraise to the same degree has to do with their particular candies.
Or you can decide that these early poll numbers and these early fundraising numbers just don't mean a whole lot and just like keep watching these folks.
I mean, we haven't seen them on anything like a debate stage where they're going to be accountable to each other.
Well, Jamelle, the two candidates who really seem to be getting people going are Elizabeth Warren who is doing the work.
She's both galvanizing crowds and also setting the legislative agenda.

And then Pete Buttigieg who every time I turn around, people I respect and admire are gushing over the guy, do you think either of them is likely to carry that forward to sort of be in the top tier of Canada?
You know, I don't know.
I mean, I'm sort of an Emily here that it's way too early.
It's March now.
We're two months in the 2019 at this point in 2015.
I want to say Scott Walker on the Republican side was sort of the guy to beat at this point in 2011 on the Republican side.
Tim Paulenty was writing high.
Neither Walker nor Paulenty made it into the fall of that year.
In 2007, I'm a Democratic side.
Hitler Clinton was the juggernaut.
John Edwards was the next sort of most formidable candidate.
And Barack Obama, while quite popular, was not was still sort of obviously a low tier candidate in the mix.
A lot can happen whether people can kind of like build, turn whatever grassroots the support they have into a sustainable campaign is not quite clear.
Whether or not someone who doesn't seem to have a ton of media attention to popular support can, through their work, create a large and sustainable campaign is also in question.
There's so much sort of on the table still that I'm not sure that it's, I'm not sure like what there is to do other than watch and observe.

And, you know, with regards to Beto or Bernie or Harris for that matter, who also seems to have quite a few supporters, I read their fundraising numbers is basically representing kind of their base level support.
Like here is where they are on the ground.
And that can change in shift depending on how things unfold.
I don't know anything habitively.
And I think the best we could do is just collect information.
It is true that nobody knows anything.

There is this talk, Emily, of Biden as a way of inoculating himself against the charge that he is infinitely old and represents a kind of discredited or a wing of the party which isn't in favor that he might pick a running mate really early.
Even as soon as the summer or the fall and the person whose name is rooted about most is Stacey Abrams.
Do you think that would help him or hurt him?
I mean to me it seems like that was kind of smack of desperation and highlight.
It would in fact highlight all the people fear about him that he is too old and that he's out of touch.
And so he's brought some, he's just getting cover rather than trying to stand up and stand for himself.
Well I think if he did it he'd have to do it and also start talking in a way that acknowledges these stances he took in the past and moves on from them,
recognizes that they were wrong.

I mean if we're going to have to re-litigate the 90s as well as the 70s and the pretty retrograde things Biden was saying then he is going to have to show clearly that he doesn't think those things anymore.
And I think that recruiting Stacey would be a great move for him in that regard.
I'm not sure I see what's in it for Stacey Abrams to tie herself to Joe Biden early on like this when it's not clear at all that he's going to win.
So that's the question I have for about it.
No is it good for Joe Biden but is it good for Stacey Abrams?
Yeah I feel the same way. Stacey Abrams is clearly a star and not even a rising star.
She's a star in the Democratic Party.
She has a chance to run for Senate in 2020 and to run again for governor in 2022.
If she is successful at increasing voter registration and helping move Georgia further into swing state status she can very well win those elections.
And in the very near future she could be a senator with an even clearer path to becoming president of the United States if she wants, if that's what she wants to do.
So I don't necessarily see what she has again from tying her star to Joe Biden especially if Joe Biden ends up crashing and burning.
Didn't Ted Cruz make a play like this at the sort of last desperate edge of the 2016 primary and it really bombed with Carly Fiorina?
Right that's right. He announced that Fiorina would be his running mate and it was people kind of just shrugged like alright that's cool.
You can do that I guess.
So we've talked a lot about the male candidates here and that may reflect some bias in actually how the media covers male and female candidates.
Emily do you think there is a distinction in how we cover the candidates based on their gender?

I think there often is but also that there's a lot of sensitivity to it that has been lacking or less in previous cycles and I've been struck this week by a number of feminists who've been pointing out that

Pete Buttigieg has been kind of swooned over in the media for seeming like an intellectual, seeming like he has, you know, there was like this thing about him learning Norwegian very quickly which I got to say I do think is pretty cool and amazing.

But people like Jill Felippovich were pointing out that Elizabeth Warren is getting, often gets criticized as being too wonky and it seemed like Mayor Pete was being celebrated for the same attributes.
I do think there is something to watch there and I was really interested in a piece this week.

I read it this week I think it's from a couple months ago by Linda Hirschman in the Washington Post where she was arguing that the media focuses too much on gender in this way that can only kind of be a part of the media.

Can only kind of reinforce stereotypes and make people too aware of whether women are really quote electable or not and that does seem important to me at this moment in particular where I think a lot of Democratic primary voters care a great deal about defeating President Trump.
And so they are looking at signals from other voters like well, you know, maybe I think that you know this female candidate would be great but if no one else is going to go for her then forget it.
So I do think there's just like such a tricky part of media coverage, social media, any kind of thinking through a broad field like this in terms of how these dynamics play out.
What are these watching each other? A broad field. A field of broads.
We're talking about the Electoral College. Thank God. Although it's hard to imagine it's going to go away.
Wouldn't it be great if there was a way to merge the college admissions scandal and the Electoral College scandal? They're both such disgracees.
Really bad uses of college. Two forms of college that need to do a great deal of repentance and reform.
But Jamelle, how did Electoral College abolition come up as an issue and does it have legs? Do you think?
So I think this week it came up as an issue because Elizabeth Warren was asked about it as a forum. She was doing in Mississippi and she came out and said, no, I think it should be abolished.
Also endorsed that view and then beta or work endorsed the view as well.

I know when I had written about it last month, I was writing apropos of Colorado sending on to the National Popular Vote Compact, which under the terms of that agreement, once the number of member states is equal to 270 electoral votes, all of those member states would give their votes to the winner of the National Popular Vote.

Regardless of how the state itself voted. If Colorado happened to go red in 2020, if there were 270 votes in the compact in the vat and Colorado happened to go red in 2020, Colorado would still give its Electoral College votes to whoever won the popular vote, even if that person didn't win the state.
So that's what I was writing off of. There's this competition spread by Warren. I think it's all very good. I've said this a lot on Twitter. I believe this very strongly.
There is no actual, like there's no justification for the Electoral College as it currently exists that makes any sense.

If you believe that one person ought to equal one vote, then the Electoral College fails that test. And the Senate fails that test too, but at least the premise of the Senate is equal representation of states.
If you're arguing against the Senate, you have to essentially say, well, it just shouldn't exist, period.
But once Americans accepted that who wins the popular vote in a state should determine who wins the electors, which more or less happened by 1804, is when states began doing that.

Once you accept that premise, the entire system falls apart. This isn't just Jamal Bui anti-electo college militant speaking, like James Madison, who helped design the whole damn thing in a letter late in life, made this point to paraphrase is more or less like this is a disaster.

If it works like this, then it is a recipe for division. So we should either return it to what we intended it to be, which was something not dissimilar to a system where parties nominate, like hand pick and nominate candidates for president.
And then a group of people sit together and decide amongst themselves who should be president.

Either you do that, which is how it was designed, or you get rid of it. And for my part, I actually think that it would have more democratic legitimacy if it literally were a Congress elected to choose a president than it does now.
Emily, what are the constitutional problems, if any, with the national popular vote interstate compact? I think people think that people think that it's a good idea.
And it's certainly, it's a lot more likely to become law than we are to have a constitutional amendment getting rid of the electoral college, which will never happen.
